awd_titl_txt: Correlative Tools for in Situ Analysis of Single Nanoparticles and their Ligands
awd_abstract_narration:
Designer gold nanoparticles consist of a metallic core surrounded by a molecular shell. Recent advances in nanoparticle growth have produced complicated star-like shapes that exhibit unique physical properties and are about 1/100 the diameter of a human hair. While the formation of the stellated structures is linked to the reaction conditions, controlled formation of particles with specific structural features remains a challenge since the growth mechanism is still unknown. With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Teri Odom of Northwestern University is developing a series analytical tools to achieve higher structural and chemical information of single nanoparticles in their native growth environments. Using this toolkit, Professor Odom and her students are identifying key intermediates in nanoparticle formation that could advance our understanding of how complex nanostructures grow. The project could pave the way to create particles with specified shapes that would have broad implications for a range of technologies, including personalized medicine and single-molecule contaminant detection. The project trains future scientists, with outreach efforts focusing on developing a new general chemistry sequence and developing graduate and junior faculty training initiatives. The project also provides training opportunities for future scientists through programs such as 'Nano Scout Day' at the Alder Planetarium.  Professor Odom also actively outreaches to local middle school students targeting underrepresented minority students. 

This proposal aims to develop correlative tools to study metal nanoparticles and their immediate surrounding environment at the near-in situ, single-particle level. The work combines multiple tools in an integrated strategy to access real-time, statistical, and multi-functional information from individual nanoparticles. Although seedless growth conditions using a gold salt and Good's buffers have been shown to promote distinct curvature regions in nanoparticles that can result in specific, exquisite macroscale properties, identification of intermediates key to nanoparticle formation has not yet been possible. To determine how nanoparticle shape and their ligand distribution interacts with local environments, high-throughput, single-nanoparticle statistical data is required. The research objectives include: (1) repurposing electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy to correlate the generation of different radicals with nanoparticle intermediate shapes and final products; (2) visualizing structural evolution of single nanoparticles during growth with wide-field differential interference contrast optical microscopy; and (3) mapping ligand distributions on different particle surfaces with one-of-a-kind tools such as time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry using particle projectiles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
* Award Title: Correlative Tools for in Situ Analysis of Single Nanoparticles and their Ligands

* Federal Award ID: 1808502

* Report Submission Period: 09/01/2018 to 08/31/2023

This proposal developed in-situ characterization tools to directly determine (1) intermediate species during nanoparticle (NP) growth and (2) ligand distribution on NP surfaces. Currently, the analysis of NP formation in situ and in real-time has been very limited. For example, although radicals are hypothesized to play an important role in NP growth, there are few reports on NP intermediates and radicals in the growth solution because of a lack of tools that could evaluate both. Furthermore, simultaneous characterization of the NP core and ligand shell is challenging because of differences in electron density (the core is electron-dense while the ligands are usually organic molecules). Direct determination of both parameters in situ will provide information on the spatial distribution of different types of ligands on different regions of NP curvatures.

To understand in detail the growth mechanism of metal NPs, we developed correlative techniques for single-particle analysis in real time. We demonstrated exquisite control over NP particle morphology and their corresponding optical properties by manipulating synthetic conditions such as buffer pH and concentration. Then, we visualized the structural evolution of anisotropic AuNPs with electron tomography to capture intermediates and understand growth mechanism. We also mapped ligand distributions on different NP curvatures with time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy, along with theoretical evidence based on molecular dynamic simulations. Taking advantage of the unique optical and physical properties of anisotropic NPs, we demonstrated their applications in optically controlled directional current and creation of single-photon emitters.

Key outcomes of the project include: (1) tuning structural features like branch length or core sizes of anisotropic gold NPs using Good?s buffers; (2) understanding seedless growth mechanism of anisotropic gold NPs using electron tomography; (3) determining ligand loading on a single metal NP using a variant of secondary ion mass spectrometry; (4) theoretically predicting DNA distribution and orientation on anisotropic gold nanoconstructs; (5) creating single-photon emitters by coupling anisotropic gold NPs with WSe2; and (6) demonstrating optically-controlled directional multiphoton photoemission from single anisotropic gold NPs.

 

Metal NPs exhibit unique physical, chemical, and optical properties because of their size and shape as well as their presenting ligands. A complete analysis of single NPs in situ is lacking yet has potential to provide mechanistic insight into their growth and to open unexpected applications. For example, how curvatures affect ligand presentation on engineered nanoconstructs is critical for understanding NP-cell interactions at the single-particle level. The project provided technological training to a work force who has combined expertise in analytical chemistry, physical chemistry, and physics. In 2023, the Odom group resumed their annual hosting of Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts from local troops as part of Nano Scout Day at Northwestern University. The hands-on laboratory developed by the Odom group allowed Scouts to convert their smartphones into microscopes with polymer lenses made on-site; students also fabricated their own chocolate micro-gratings molded against a master pattern. These activities aimed to encourage young children to consider science and technology as a career and highlighted the Odom group?s expertise in nanoscale synthesis, nanofabrication, and photonics.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Teri W Odom
